docs.title: Globi Workshop Setup Guide
docs.text: This guide will walk you through downloading all of the required dependencies to be able to work with the globi repo.

docs.title: What You'll Install
docs.text:
This workshop requires five essential tools:

  1. Docker - Runs the Hatchet server locally in containers
  2. Git - Version control for managing code
  3. uv - Fast Python package manager
  4. Python 3.12+ - The programming language for this project
  5. make - Build automation tool (Windows only; macOS includes this by default)

docs.title: Step 1: Install Docker
docs.text: Docker lets you run the Hatchet server in an isolated container. You'll need Docker Desktop for your operating system.

docs.title: macOS
docs.text:
1. Download Docker Desktop for Mac
  2. Open the .dmg file and drag Docker to your Applications folder
  3. Launch Docker Desktop from Applications
  4. Verify the installation by opening Terminal and running: 
    docker --version
    You should see output like: Docker version 24.0.x

Troubleshooting: Command not found

If you see docker: command not found, Docker may not be in your PATH. Add it by running: bash export PATH=$PATH:$HOME/.docker/bin To make this permanent, add the line above to your ~/.zshrc or ~/.bash_profile file.

docs.title: Windows
docs.text:
1. Download Docker Desktop for Windows
  2. Run the installer and follow the installation wizard
  3. Restart your computer when prompted
  4. Launch Docker Desktop from the Start menu
  5. Verify the installation by opening PowerShell or Command Prompt and running: 
    docker --version
    You should see output like: Docker version 24.0.x

docs.title: Linux (Ubuntu/Debian)
docs.text:
1. Update your package index: 
    sudo apt-get update
  2. Install Docker: 
    sudo apt-get install docker.io
  3. Start Docker and enable it to start on boot: 
    sudo systemctl start docker
sudo systemctl enable docker
  4. Add your user to the docker group so you can run Docker without sudo: 
    sudo usermod -aG docker $USER
  5. Log out and log back in for the group change to take effect
  6. Verify the installation: 
    docker --version
    You should see output like: Docker version 24.0.x

docs.title: Step 2: Install Git
docs.text: Git is essential for version control. Let's check if you already have it.

docs.title: Check for Existing Installation
docs.text:
Open your terminal and run:

git --version

If you see a version number like git version 2.x.x, you're all set! Skip to Step 3.

docs.title: Install Git
docs.text:
If Git isn't installed, visit the official Git installation page and follow the instructions for your operating system.

After installation, verify it worked:

git --version

docs.title: Step 3: Install uv and Python
docs.text: This project uses Python 3.12+ and uv for package management. We recommend installing uv first, then using it to manage Python versions.

docs.title: macOS/Linux
docs.text:
1. Install uv with a single command:
curl -LsSf https://astral.sh/uv/install.sh | sh
  1. Verify the installation:
uv --version

You should see output like: uv 0.x.x

  1. Check if you have Python 3.12+:
python --version

or

python3 --version
  1. Install Python using uv if needed:

If your Python version is below 3.12 or you don't have Python installed, use uv to install it:

uv python install 3.12

For more details, check the uv Python installation guide.

  1. Verify Python installation: 
    python --version
    You should see: Python 3.12.x or higher

docs.title: Windows
docs.text:
1. Install uv using PowerShell:
powershell -ExecutionPolicy ByPass -c "irm https://astral.sh/uv/install.ps1 | iex"
  1. Verify the installation:
uv --version

You should see output like: uv 0.x.x

  1. Check if you have Python 3.12+:
python --version
  1. Install Python using uv if needed:

If your Python version is below 3.12 or you don't have Python installed:

uv python install 3.12
  1. Verify Python installation: 
    python --version
    You should see: Python 3.12.x or higher

Why uv?

uv is significantly faster than pip and provides better dependency resolution. It's built in Rust and designed to be a drop-in replacement for pip, pip-tools, and virtualenv.

docs.title: Step 4: Install make (Windows Only)
docs.text:
macOS and Linux users: You already have make installed! Skip to the next section.

Windows users: You'll need to install make to use the project's build commands.

docs.title: Using Chocolatey (Recommended)
docs.text:
If you have Chocolatey installed:

choco install make

docs.title: Alternative: Using Scoop
docs.text:
If you prefer Scoop:

scoop install make

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text:
make --version

You should see output like: GNU Make 4.x

docs.title: Step 6: Create Environment Configuration File
docs.text:
Run the following command in your terminal: 

make hatchet-token

  • Copy your client token

  • Paste it into the .env.local.host.hatchet amd the .env.local.hatchet files: 

    HATCHET_CLIENT_TOKEN=your_token_here

  • Save the .env file

Step 5: Start the workers
docs.text:
Check that this step runs. When it does, run the following command:

   make engine

If you are on a Mac, you may see this error the first time you do this 

target simulations: failed to solve: image "123456789012.dkr.ecr.us-east-1.amazonaws.com/hatchet/globi:latest": already exists

make: *** [engine] Error 1

If you encounter this, try re-running the make engine command - this should solve the issue.

If you want to stop the server, you can run this: 

hatchet server stop

docs.title: Step 7: Run a Test Simulation
docs.text:
Now you're ready to run your first simulation using the mock data!

  1. Make sure both Hatchet workers are running

  2. Run the simulation command:

make cli submit manifest -- --path {PATH_TO_MANIFEST} --grid-run

  1. Monitor the simulation progress:

  2. Open the Hatchet UI in your browser (http://localhost:8080)

  3. Navigate to the "Workflows" or "Runs" section
  4. You should see your simulation job appear

  5. Watch as it gets allocated to a worker and begins processing

  6. Wait for the simulation to complete:

  7. The status will change from "Running" to "Completed" when finished
  8. You can click on the workflow to see detailed logs and outputs

Once you are done with the simulation runs, you can stop the Docker images by running: 

make down

docs.title: Step 8: View simulation results
docs.text:
AFter running the simulation, you should the following in your terminal: 

versioned_experiment:
  base_experiment:
    experiment: scythe_experiment_simulate_globi_building
    run_name: Cambridge_UK/dryrun/Baseline
    storage_settings:
      BUCKET: globi-bucket
      BUCKET_PREFIX: globi
  version:
    major: 1
    minor: 0
    patch: 0
timestamp: '2026-01-23T13:57:36.233154'

Copy the run_name so that you can use it for the results get command.

make cli get experiment  --run-name {YOUR_RUN_NAME_HERE}

If you have done lots of different simulations, and you want to access specific versions of your runs, then check what version you want to access. It should be in the form x.x.x., e.g., if the version is major.minor.patch.

You have the ability to also choose your desired output_dir to save to a specific location. Overall, the request becomes: 

make cli get experiment  --run-name {YOUR_RUN_NAME_HERE} --version {VERSION} --output_dir {YOUR_CHOSEN_OUTPUT_DIR}

You will see a message telling you where the results have been saved to.

docs.title: Docker Issues
docs.text:
• Docker daemon not running: Make sure Docker Desktop is running before executing commands
  • Permission denied: On Linux, ensure your user is in the docker group (see Linux Docker installation step)

docs.title: EnergyPlus Issues
docs.text: • EnergyPlus not found: Verify EnergyPlus is in your system PATH

docs.title: Hatchet Issues
docs.text:
• Workers not appearing: Check that both worker terminals are running without errors
  • Connection refused: Ensure the Hatchet server is running and accessible at http://localhost:8080
  • Token errors: Verify your HATCHET_CLIENT_TOKEN in the .env file is correct

docs.title: Python/uv Issues
docs.text:
• Module not found: Run uv sync --all-extras --all-groups again to ensure all dependencies are installed
  • Python version error: Verify you have Python 3.12 or higher with python --version

docs.title: Essential Commands
docs.text:
# Start simulation worker
make hatchet-simulation-worker

# Start fanouts worker (in separate terminal)
make hatchet-fanouts-worker

# Run a simulation
hatchet worker dev --run-cmd "uv run --env-file .env globi submit manifest --path data/partners/LOCATION/manifest.yml --grid-run"

# Check Hatchet UI
open http://localhost:8080

docs.text:
